caseTitle: IN THE MATTER OF THE ESTATE OF JAMES TAYLOR, DECEASED
summary: In this 1941 West Africa Court of Appeal case from Accra, Joseph Afolabi Lagos appealed his murder conviction for the killing of Haruna Moshie, a Preventive Service officer, during a cigarette smuggling operation. The prosecution relied heavily on the testimony of two accomplices, Nicholas Kwaku and Emmanuel Kodjo, both of whom implicated the appellant. A key issue was the trial judge's direction to the jury that the appellant's silence when allegations were made against him at the crime scene constituted corroboration. The appellate court held that while silence can amount to corroboration under special circumstances, the jury must be properly directed to assess whether the silence implied admission. In this case, such direction was absent, amounting to misdirection. Additionally, the court upheld the admissibility of evidence obtained when the accused was taken to the scene before formal charge, recognizing exceptional circumstances. The appeal was allowed, and the appellant was acquitted.
